Hands-on_Ex06

  • Show All Code
  • Hide All Code
  • View Source
Take-home Exercise
Author

Shermainn

Published

May 20, 2025

Modified

May 21, 2025

Overview:

To plot a calendar heatmap by using ggplot2 package.

Install and Load Package:

Code 
pacman::p_load(scales, viridis, lubridate, ggthemes,
               gridExtra, readxl, knitr, data.table,
               CGPfunctions, ggHoriPlot, tidyverse)

Import Data:

Code 
attacks <- read_csv("data/eventlog.csv")

Examine data structure:

Code 
kable(head(attacks))
timestamp source_country tz
2015-03-12 15:59:16 CN Asia/Shanghai
2015-03-12 16:00:48 FR Europe/Paris
2015-03-12 16:02:26 CN Asia/Shanghai
2015-03-12 16:02:38 US America/Chicago
2015-03-12 16:03:22 CN Asia/Shanghai
2015-03-12 16:03:45 CN Asia/Shanghai

Data Prep:

Step 1:

2 new fields need to be derived. wkday and hour was created.

Code 
make_hr_wkday <- function(ts, sc, tz) {
  real_times <- ymd_hms(ts, 
                        tz = tz[1], 
                        quiet = TRUE)
  dt <- data.table(source_country = sc,
                   wkday = weekdays(real_times),
                   hour = hour(real_times))
  return(dt)
}

#ymd_hms() and hour() are from lubridate package, and
#weekdays() is a base R function.

Step 2:

Code 
wkday_levels <- c('Saturday', 'Friday', 
                  'Thursday', 'Wednesday', 
                  'Tuesday', 'Monday', 
                  'Sunday')

attacks <- attacks %>%
  group_by(tz) %>%
  do(make_hr_wkday(.$timestamp, 
                   .$source_country, 
                   .$tz)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(wkday = factor(
    wkday, levels = wkday_levels),
    hour  = factor(
      hour, levels = 0:23))

#Beside extracting the necessary data into attacks data frame, mutate() of dplyr package is used to convert wkday and hour fields into factor so theyâ€™ll be ordered when plotting
Code 
kable(head(attacks))
tz source_country wkday hour
Africa/Cairo BG Saturday 20
Africa/Cairo TW Sunday 6
Africa/Cairo TW Sunday 8
Africa/Cairo CN Sunday 11
Africa/Cairo US Sunday 15
Africa/Cairo CA Monday 11

Build Heatmap:

Code 
grouped <- attacks %>% 
  count(wkday, hour) %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  na.omit()

ggplot(grouped, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
coord_equal() +
scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
labs(x = NULL, 
     y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day") +
theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
      legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
      legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )

Things to note:

  • a tibble data table called grouped is derived by aggregating the attack by wkday and hour fields.

  • a new field called n is derived by using group_by() and count() functions.

  • na.omit() is used to exclude missing value.

  • geom_tile() is used to plot tiles (grids) at each x and y position. color and size arguments are used to specify the border color and line size of the tiles.

  • theme_tufte() of ggthemes package is used to remove unnecessary chart junk. To learn which visual components of default ggplot2 have been excluded, you are encouraged to comment out this line to examine the default plot.

  • coord_equal() is used to ensure the plot will have an aspect ratio of 1:1.

  • scale_fill_gradient() function is used to creates a two colour gradient (low-high).

Build multiple heatmaps

Example: Top 4 countries with highest attacks

Step 1: derive attack by country object

  • count the number of attacks by country,

  • calculate the percent of attackes by country, and

  • save the results in a tibble data frame.

Code 
attacks_by_country <- count(
  attacks, source_country) %>%
  mutate(percent = percent(n/sum(n))) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))

Step 2: Preparing the tidy data frame

Code 
#Extract attack records
top4 <- attacks_by_country$source_country[1:4]
top4_attacks <- attacks %>%
  filter(source_country %in% top4) %>%
  count(source_country, wkday, hour) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(source_country = factor(
    source_country, levels = top4)) %>%
  na.omit()

Step 3: Plot the maps

Code 
ggplot(top4_attacks, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
  geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
  coord_equal() +
  scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
  facet_wrap(~source_country, ncol = 2) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks on top 4 countries by weekday and time of day") +
  theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )

Cycle Plot

Step 1: Data Import

Code 
air <- read_excel("data/arrivals_by_air.xlsx")

Step 2: Derive month and year fields

Code 
air$month <- factor(month(air$`Month-Year`), 
                    levels=1:12, 
                    labels=month.abb, 
                    ordered=TRUE) 
air$year <- year(ymd(air$`Month-Year`))

Step 3: Extract Target Country

Code 
Vietnam <- air %>% 
  select(`Vietnam`, 
         month, 
         year) %>%
  filter(year >= 2010)

Step 4: Computing year average arrivals by month

Code 
hline.data <- Vietnam %>% 
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(avgvalue = mean(`Vietnam`))

Step 5: Plot cycle plot

Code 
library(ggrepel)
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Vietnam,
            aes(x=year, 
                y=`Vietnam`, 
                group=month), 
            colour="black") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept=avgvalue), 
             data=hline.data, 
             linetype=6, 
             colour="red", 
             size=0.5) + 
  geom_text_repel() +
  facet_grid(~month) +
  labs(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
       title = "Visitor arrivals from Vietnam by air, Jan 2010-Dec 2019") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("No. of Visitors") +
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

Slopegraph

Step 1: Data Import

Code 
rice <- read_csv("data/rice.csv")

Step 2: Plot slopegraph

  • For effective data visualisation design, factor() is used convert the value type of Year field from numeric to factor.
Code 
rice %>% 
  mutate(Year = factor(Year)) %>%
  filter(Year %in% c(1961, 1980)) %>%
  newggslopegraph(Year, Yield, Country,
                Title = "Rice Yield of Top 11 Asian Counties",
                SubTitle = "1961-1980")

Overview:

To plot a calendar heatmap by using ggplot2 package.

Install and Load Package:

```{r}
pacman::p_load(scales, viridis, lubridate, ggthemes,
               gridExtra, readxl, knitr, data.table,
               CGPfunctions, ggHoriPlot, tidyverse)
```

Import Data:

```{r}
attacks <- read_csv("data/eventlog.csv")
```

Examine data structure:

```{r}
kable(head(attacks))
```

Data Prep:

Step 1:

2 new fields need to be derived. wkday and hour was created.

```{r}
make_hr_wkday <- function(ts, sc, tz) {
  real_times <- ymd_hms(ts, 
                        tz = tz[1], 
                        quiet = TRUE)
  dt <- data.table(source_country = sc,
                   wkday = weekdays(real_times),
                   hour = hour(real_times))
  return(dt)
}

#ymd_hms() and hour() are from lubridate package, and
#weekdays() is a base R function.
```

Step 2:

```{r}
wkday_levels <- c('Saturday', 'Friday', 
                  'Thursday', 'Wednesday', 
                  'Tuesday', 'Monday', 
                  'Sunday')

attacks <- attacks %>%
  group_by(tz) %>%
  do(make_hr_wkday(.$timestamp, 
                   .$source_country, 
                   .$tz)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(wkday = factor(
    wkday, levels = wkday_levels),
    hour  = factor(
      hour, levels = 0:23))

#Beside extracting the necessary data into attacks data frame, mutate() of dplyr package is used to convert wkday and hour fields into factor so theyâ€™ll be ordered when plotting
```

```{r}
kable(head(attacks))
```

Build Heatmap:

```{r}
grouped <- attacks %>% 
  count(wkday, hour) %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  na.omit()

ggplot(grouped, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
coord_equal() +
scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
labs(x = NULL, 
     y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks by weekday and time of day") +
theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
      legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
      legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
```

Things to note:

-   a tibble data table called *grouped* is derived by aggregating the attack by *wkday* and *hour* fields.

-   a new field called *n* is derived by using `group_by()` and `count()` functions.

-   `na.omit()` is used to exclude missing value.

-   `geom_tile()` is used to plot tiles (grids) at each x and y position. `color` and `size` arguments are used to specify the border color and line size of the tiles.

-   [`theme_tufte()`](https://jrnold.github.io/ggthemes/reference/theme_tufte.html) of [**ggthemes**](https://jrnold.github.io/ggthemes/reference/index.html) package is used to remove unnecessary chart junk. To learn which visual components of default ggplot2 have been excluded, you are encouraged to comment out this line to examine the default plot.

-   `coord_equal()` is used to ensure the plot will have an aspect ratio of 1:1.

-   `scale_fill_gradient()` function is used to creates a two colour gradient (low-high).

Build multiple heatmaps

Example: Top 4 countries with highest attacks

Step 1: derive attack by country object

-   count the number of attacks by country,

-   calculate the percent of attackes by country, and

-   save the results in a tibble data frame.

```{r}
attacks_by_country <- count(
  attacks, source_country) %>%
  mutate(percent = percent(n/sum(n))) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))
```

Step 2: Preparing the tidy data frame

```{r}
#Extract attack records
top4 <- attacks_by_country$source_country[1:4]
top4_attacks <- attacks %>%
  filter(source_country %in% top4) %>%
  count(source_country, wkday, hour) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(source_country = factor(
    source_country, levels = top4)) %>%
  na.omit()
```

Step 3: Plot the maps

```{r}
ggplot(top4_attacks, 
       aes(hour, 
           wkday, 
           fill = n)) + 
  geom_tile(color = "white", 
          size = 0.1) + 
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") + 
  coord_equal() +
  scale_fill_gradient(name = "# of attacks",
                    low = "sky blue", 
                    high = "dark blue") +
  facet_wrap(~source_country, ncol = 2) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL, 
     title = "Attacks on top 4 countries by weekday and time of day") +
  theme(axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 7),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5),
        legend.title = element_text(size = 8),
        legend.text = element_text(size = 6) )
```

Cycle Plot

Step 1: Data Import

```{r}
air <- read_excel("data/arrivals_by_air.xlsx")
```

Step 2: Derive month and year fields

```{r}
air$month <- factor(month(air$`Month-Year`), 
                    levels=1:12, 
                    labels=month.abb, 
                    ordered=TRUE) 
air$year <- year(ymd(air$`Month-Year`))
```

Step 3: Extract Target Country

```{r}
Vietnam <- air %>% 
  select(`Vietnam`, 
         month, 
         year) %>%
  filter(year >= 2010)
```

Step 4: Computing year average arrivals by month

```{r}
hline.data <- Vietnam %>% 
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(avgvalue = mean(`Vietnam`))
```

Step 5: Plot cycle plot

```{r}
library(ggrepel)
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Vietnam,
            aes(x=year, 
                y=`Vietnam`, 
                group=month), 
            colour="black") +
  geom_hline(aes(yintercept=avgvalue), 
             data=hline.data, 
             linetype=6, 
             colour="red", 
             size=0.5) + 
  geom_text_repel() +
  facet_grid(~month) +
  labs(axis.text.x = element_blank(),
       title = "Visitor arrivals from Vietnam by air, Jan 2010-Dec 2019") +
  xlab("") +
  ylab("No. of Visitors") +
  theme_tufte(base_family = "Helvetica") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))
```

Slopegraph

Step 1: Data Import

```{r}
rice <- read_csv("data/rice.csv")
```

Step 2: Plot slopegraph

-   For effective data visualisation design, `factor()` is used convert the value type of *Year* field from numeric to factor.

```{r}
rice %>% 
  mutate(Year = factor(Year)) %>%
  filter(Year %in% c(1961, 1980)) %>%
  newggslopegraph(Year, Yield, Country,
                Title = "Rice Yield of Top 11 Asian Counties",
                SubTitle = "1961-1980")
```
